title: jesus statue lake michigan first viewing years
story: The ft statue of Christ on the cross - the only such monument placed under fresh water in the world - is around  yards from the shore at Petoskey, Michigan.Hundreds headed to the town, near the US-Canada border, on Saturday to gaze at the stunning relic through a hole carved through ft of dense ice.The tragic story behind the lb marble statue - which is placed ft under in the murky depths of the Great Lake - dates all the way back to .It was then that it was bought following a tragic farming accident in the nearby town of Bad Axe that left a -year-old boy dead, according to Inside Edition.His grieving family purchased it from craftsmen in Italy for £, - which in todays money would be worth , .But they refused to keep it after the cross was damaged during shipment across the Atlantic.The stunning statue then made its way into the hands of a local ing club following an insurance sale in .Members then gained permission to lower it into the lake as a tribute to a er who had recently lost his le in nearby Torch Lake.It has since gone on to become a touching symbol of remembrance to all those who have lost their lives at sea.This weekends viewing saw  people take to the ice to look at the statue and pay their respects, according to WPBN.Some ventured from as far as Texas and Alaska to brave the cold and view the crucix.It is the first public viewing of the statue from the surface since  - the last time weather conditions allowed for people to walk out onto the ice.The statue is expected to last under water for a total of  years before erosion sets in.

title: woman sawed off hand make insurance claim
story: The -year-old enlisted the help of her family in an apparent injury claim fraud, according to detectives in Slovenia.She was rushed to hospital in the capital Ljubljana claiming that she was the victim of a horric accident while cutting branches.But the woman left the severed hand at home in a deliberate attempt to ensure the injury was permanent, cops claim.She and a relative have been arrested and each face up to eight years in prisonconvicted, BBC News reports.They allegedly took out an insurance policy in recent weeks and had stood to gain around €, .The money would have been paid out in monthly instalments worth €,under their policy.Two other family members had been arrested on suspicion of involvement in the alleged fraud earlier this year but were later released.The severed hand was recovered by authorities in time for medics to sew it back on, officials say.

title: meghan markle schoolmate shares picture princess
story: Actress Katharine McPhee revealed she had performed in school musicals with Meghan Markle as a teen - with the now royal recognising her when they met last week.Speaking on Good Morning Britain, the -year-old American actress said: I went to school with Meghan Markle, I was in middle school, she was in high school.My sister was in her class, they were the same age.She was always lovely, always talented and always put together.Katharine, who is London starring in the West end production Waitress, laughed as the flashback photograph was again shown onscreen, showing the two students smiling in outfits for their school musical.The photograph shows the pair in full make-up and sporting bright red lips for the stage show.Sharing a caption of the pic, Katharine last week wrote: Meghan and I did musicals together as kids.She grew up to be the Duchess of Sussex and I grew up to star on the West End, so same leyou ask me.They both appear to be fresh off the stage and still in costume, although Katharine didn’t reveal which production they starred in.Both Meghan and Katharine grew up in Los Angeles, with pregnant Meghan three years older, but it wasn’t widely known that they were friends.And Katharine revealed she had been flattered that the Duchess of Sussex had remembered her, as well as her sister who had been in the same grade as her, when she met her again at the WE Day UK event at Wembley Arena in London last week.She revealed: I just saw her last week and I dont have a picture even though there is one out there but you know, the royals have to approve of everything.I did get to reunite with her, and it was so sweet. She remembered me but she remembered my sister as well because they were in actual class together.Katharine, who is currently in London for the Broadway show waitress, even extended an invite to the performance to her old school pal.She said: We did invite her - were going to try to get her to come to the show.Meghan went on to become a successful actress, getting her big break in the legal drama Suits in .Katharine, also an actress as well as a singer, was a runner-up in the fth season of American Idol, and released a debut album in .She went on to release four more albums, and also had roles in Ugly Betty, Community, CSI:NY, Family Guy and The House Bunny.Katharine is currently starring in the West End production of Waitress, which opens at the Adelphi Theatre on February .

title: wetherspoons museum hotel jobs wolverhampton
story: Plans to renovate The Moon Under Water pub in Wolverhampton have now been approved by the local council.The Black Country boozer will be expanded and the floor above it, which has been empty for the last  years, converted into a hotel.It will tell the story of the leading British boozing institution and create  jobs.Businessman Tim Martin opened the first Wetherspoons in  which led to the creation of a chain of much loved no-fuss boozers, where any time of day is suitable for a full English and a pint.Its now established a UK-wide reputation for offering punters cheap dinners and a unique carpet experience.And now the museum and hotel are set to pour new le into a pub which has stood empty for more than  years.Wetherspoon spokesman Eddie Gershon said: We have great plans for the popular The Moon Under Water pub.We believe this will be great for the pub, its customers and just as importantly the city itself.We feel the museum will prove popular with people who want to know more of the history of the company and see artefacts from the past.The fact that Wetherspoons wishes to house it in Wolverhampton is positive for the city.The Moon Under Water is on the ground floor of Wolverhamptons sprawling former Co-op department store building.The , square feet Art Deco space was a jewel in the citys crown for decades but has stood empty for more than  years, with only the ground floor still open for business.From the day it opened in , customers travelled from across the Midlands to shop there but in recent years the upstairs storeys have been boarded up with crumbling walls, collapsed ceilings and rotten window frames.Wetherspoon operates around  pubs, including the chain of Lloyds No  bars and a growing number of Wetherspoon hotels.

title: brexit vote time results tonight
story: But what time is the Brexit vote and what are the possible upshots we can expect  Heres what we know.May is expected to chair a cabinet meeting on Tuesday morning before the motion is debated in Parliament in the afternoon.MPs Meaningful vote on the PM’s revised deal will start at around pm and the results will be announced soon after.Mrs May lost by a thumping  votes in January.During yesterdays rollercoaster day in Brexit:Theresa May will hold a second vote on her Brexit deal today - and could still suffer another crushing lossBrexiteers dont think its enough to win them over.A  of eight Brexiteer ‘lawyers’ – including DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds – will rule whether they believe Mrs May has done enough later today.If Mays deal is rejected, a further vote has been promised for March  on whether the UK should leave without a deal.If that No Deal is rejected, MPs could also get a vote on Thursday on whether to request a delay to Brexit from the EU.Another option stands to be a general election, which Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn previously raised the possibility of.Another referendum may also be on the card, after nearly a million people marched in support of a Peoples Vote, campaigning for a second referendum to be held on Brexit.But both the Conservatives and opposition party Labour have all-but ruled out the possibility of another vote.And finally, option number five is a no confidence vote, which May has previously survived, meaning she cannot be challenged for another three years by her colleagues.However, Labour could call a vote of No Confidence in the Government - which leader Jeremy Corbyn has threatened to do.Now is the time to come together, to back this improved Brexit deal, and to deliver on the instruction of the British people, she begged MPs.A spokesperson for kingmaker MPs the DUP said last night: We note the Prime Ministers latest statement and update on our EU exit negotiations. These publications need careful analysis.We will be taking appropriate advice, scrutinising the text line by line and forming our own Judgement.Labours Sir Keir Starmer said the tweaks adds nothing to the deal and it still wouldnt be good enough for them to get behind.Tory Damian Collins said tonight: I will be voting against the government’s motion on EU withdrawal. Nothing has really changed since last November. We have the power to apply to an arbitration  to leave the back stop, but not the right to leave by ourselves.Top Tory Jacob Rees-Mogg said it was too early to tell but said it was clearly a step in the right direction.Brexiteer Steve Baker said last night he was waiting to see the text of the deal, telling Sky News: We may or may not be able to support it.Britains departure deadline is pm on Friday, March , .In between this date and December , , some form of transition period is expected.The grace period will allow businesses and others to prepare for the day the new post-Brexit rules between the UK and EU begin.Free movement will continue throughout the transition period.The UK will be able to make its own trade deals, however, they will not come into force until January , .Future relations between the UK and EU have been subject to extensive negotiations, but it is not yet known how things will work in the long term.Both sides hope they can agree within six months about issues such as trade, travel and security.The deal could then be given the go ahead in time for the day the UK leaves.

title: student stung scorpion plane seat canada
story: Student Quin Maltais said she felt a tickling sensation followed by a piercing pain as she was nipped by the venomous critter.She leapt to her feet and found the scorpion crawling into the fold of the seat on the Air Transat jet in Canada.Quin how she started to feel a fluttering motion on her lower back near the end of a four-hour flight from Toronto to Calgary.She told CBC: I just kind of ignored it.As soon as the lights turned off, closer to when were literally about to land, I felt the piercing pain on my lower back, like, oh, my God, something bit me.She said she was freaking out, trying to grab her jumper, but couldnt take off her seatbelt to see what it was.Quin added: The lights turned on, I looked into the ball of bundled sweater that I had but nothing was there.I looked behind me on the seat and then I saw movement and there was a scorpion that was in the fold toward the back of the chair.It was on my back for the past  minutes. It was like four inches maybe.She claims a stewardess initially tried to claim what she felt was a only gum wrapper - but then she checked again and spotted the scorpion between the seats.Paramedics escorted Quin off the plane when it landed at .pm on February .She said: I had a full-fledged panic attack. Paramedics had to kind of keep me strapped to a heart monitor for a while cause I was just unable to calm down.Transat said the scorpion was captured once all passengers had got off the plane.The airline said it did not know how it got there. Staff handed it to authorities.A spokesman told CBC: Although this is an extremely rare situation, it can unfortunately occur.Our teams followed the protocols in place and a complete inspection of the aircraft, as well as an extermination process, were carried out.Scorpions pack a powerful sting in their tails, but most species are not dangerous to humans.Last month a terrying video showed a fearsome -inch scorpion crawling on overhead lockers on a Lion Air jet bound for Jakarta.And in  a scorpion fell on a passengers head and stung his hand on a United Airlines flight from Mexico to Calgary.

title: kate middleton broody toddlers northern ireland
story: The Duchess of Cambridge was eager to join the little ones and fellow parents as they played at a childrens centre in Lambeth, South London, this morning.Sitting on the play mat with fellow mums, Kate laughed and joked with the sweet toddlers at the Henry Fawcett Childrens Centre.As she played with the little ones, the duchess reportedly told them one of her favourite things in le is getting hugs from her children.The visit comes just weeks after the -year-old admitted she was feeling broody during a visit to Northern Ireland - laughing William would be a little worried at the idea of a fourth child.Kate and Prince William have three children together - five-year-old Prince George, three-year-old Princess Charlotte and little Prince Louis, who is not yet one.The mum said her own little own, Louis, was bombing around on his walker, adding: Louis just wants to pull himself up all the time. He has got these little walkers and is bombing around in them.The duchess was today flying solo, joining parents and toddlers at the Lambeth Early Action Partnership, and Parent and Infant Relationship Service.And she sympathised with one tot, nine-month-old Kameron, who started to cry in the group, cooing: Theres so many people here.Other toddlers to steal the show were -month-old twins Kamina and Kashay, who jumped up and down and waved at cameras as they played with fellow twins Noah and Charlie,  months.The duchess had been all smiles as she arrived at the centre in Lambeth, South London, wearing a £ shirt by Gucci and £ trousers by Jigsaw as she arrived to learn about the work done to support young kids and their families.The trousers are the same that Kate wore for a visit to Cyprus last year - with the wide-legged style similar to that favoured by in-law Meghan Markle.Despite rumours of a rt between the royal women before Christmas, the pair seemed delighted to see each other at the Commonwealth Day service yesterday.The Fab Four - Prince William and Kate and Prince Harry and Meghan - chatted happily as they were reunited at Westminster Abbey on Monday.And luckily for Kate, the Royal family is expecting to welcome another baby with the Duchess of Sussex expecting to give birth in a matter of weeks.The mum-of-three has prioritised visits to organisations that focus on Englands youth this year - visiting a number of schools and child play centres in the past few weeks.Last month, she spoke with children at teachers at two London schools to mark Childrens Mental Health Week.And at the start of the year, she shared jokes with young students at Islington Community Garden.But the duchess was stumped when one cheeky student asked herthe Queen had ever eaten pizza.The -year-old royal has previously spoken out about the importance of supporting kids mental health, encouraging them to be comfortable in their own skin.She even penned a personal essay about mental health issues with Huffington Post UK, writing: The mental health of our children must be seen as every bit as important as their physical health.For too long we have been embarrassed to admit when our children need emotional or psychiatric help, worried that the stigma associated with these problems would be detrimental to their futures.The mum has been a patron of charity PlaceBe since  and has worked with husband Prince William and Prince Harry in their Heads Together campaign.Tonight, Kate will attend the Portrait Gala  to meet members of the gallerys Youth Forum and view artwork produced by some of the National Portrait Gallerys outreach programmes.It is the third gala she has attended and will raise money to support the gallerys work.It comes after a busy day for the Royal Family yesterday, with the senior members attending a Commonwealth Day service at Westminster Abbey.Meghan and Kate greeted each other with a warm kiss on each cheek as the Queen arrived.Speaking exclusively to Fabulous Online, body language expert Judi said: It was clear Kate and Meghan were keen to signal bonds of warm friendship yesterday, rather than the either distant or over-congruent displays from the last couple of outings.

title: boeing 737 max planes turn around uk france ban
story: The UKs Civil Aviation Authority grounded all Max jets from pm over safety fears and then Europes EASA agency followed with a continent-wide ban from pm.According to the Flightradar tracking website, two Turkish Airlines planes turned for home as Britain and a host of other European countries announced a ban on the jet in the wake of Sundays Ethiopian Airlines disaster.One plane was on its way to Gatwick and the other to Birmingham when they were seen heading back.The CAA said Turkish Airlines turned its planes back so they wouldnt get stuck in the UK, unable to take off again after a safety directive.The airline itself said it was grounding its entire fleet until the uncertainty affecting safety is cleared and flights across Europe turned back.Flightradar showed one of its flights on its way to Tel Aviv turning around and heading back to Stockholm while over Romania.France, Germany, Austria, Italy and Ireland today became the latest countries to ban the planes from the air.And this evening the European Union Aviation Safety Agency announced a Europe-wide ban on Max  and Max  jets that comes into force at pm.Elsewhere in Europe, budget airline Norwegian announced that it was grounding its fleet  Max  planes.In a day of travel chaos:German transport minister Andreas Scheuer said  “until all doubts are cleared up, I have ordered that German airspace be closed for the Boeing  Max with immediate effect.The Irish Aviation Authority added: The IAAs decision has been made taking account of the unprecedented loss of two Boeing  MAX in recent months.The UK ban means none of the planes will be able to travel in and out of the UK or fly over its air space.TUI, which has five of the planes, said it would use a dferent model to get passengers to their destinations.Brian Strutton, general secretary of pilots union Balpa, welcomed the ban saying: Safety must come first.It is too early to know the cause of the latest crash and it is vital that air accident investigators carry out a thorough investigation to identy the cause so that measures to prevent future accidents can be put in place.The  Max  has also been grounded in China, Australia, South Korea, Singapore, Indonesia, Morocco, Mongolia, Malaysia, Poland and Oman.But US authorities said they would not be taking any decision until they have seen further evidence.Boeing itself said it had full confidence in the safety of the  MAX fleet.The company said: We understand that regulatory agencies and customers have made decisions that they believe are most appropriate for their home markets.Well continue to engage with them to ensure they have the information needed to have confidence in operating their fleets.Donald Trump weighed in by slamming modern plane design, claiming “complexity creates danger” and hinders pilots from making “split second decisions” to ensure their passengers’ safety.He added: “I don’t know about you, but I don’t want Albert Einstein to be my pilot.A spokesperson for the CAA said: “Our thoughts go out to everyone affected by the tragic accident in Ethiopia yesterday.There are currently five Boeing  Max  aircraft registered and operational in the United Kingdom. A sixth aircraft is due to enter operation later this week.The US Federal Aviation Administrationis responsible for certying all Boeing  Max  models and it is the European Aviation Safety Agencythat validates this certication across the EU, including the UK.The UK Civil Aviation Authority is liaising very closely with the EASA as the facts of this incident are established.EASA said: As a precautionary measure, EASA has published today an Airworthiness Directive, suspending all flight operations of all Boeing Model - MAX and - MAX aeroplanes in Europe.The accident investigation is led by the Ethiopian Authorities with the support of the National Transportation Safety Board, as the aircraft was designed and built in the United States.EASA has offered their assistance in supporting the accident investigation.TUI has the only five  Max  aircraft operated by a UK-based airline and was due to begin flying a sixth later this week.They said in a statement: Any customers due to fly home today on a  MAX  from their holiday will be flown back on another aircraft.Customers due to travel in the coming days will also travel on holiday as planned on other aircraft.Norwegian Airlines has  in its fleet and serves London Gatwick, Manchester and Edinburgh.They confirmed they had suspended flights of the aircraft in accordance with the CAAs instruction and apologised for the inconvenience to passengers.Worried holidaymakers had taken to social media to express their fears over using the planes to fly in and out of Britain.Michael Bibby said: TUI need to ground the death plane until Boeing provide a proper fix!While Lucy Barcoo asked TUI: Can you please tell me which type of aircraft my flight home from Ibiza will be on please  Very concerned about the Boeing  Max.Kenneth Bird tweeted: Hi there @TUIUKcares @TUIUK @TUIGroup how come you haven’t grounded your Boeing  Max s  They fly over my house! Many other airlines have grounded theirs as a precautionary move.James Bunker said: @TUIUK we are due to fly to Fuerteventura the day after tomorrow with you guys but are a little worried about the recent news for your Boeing  MAX aircraft. Can you confirm it’s % safe  @TUIUKcares #tui #.Air Italy - in constant dialogue with the authoritiesS - constantly keeping in touch with the manufacturerSouthwest Airlines - in contact with BoeingFiji Airways - training... meets highest safety standardsWestJet - monitoring the situation closelyLOT Polish Airlines - closely monitoring the situationAmerican Airlines - full confidence in the aircraft... will closely monitor the investigationIcelandair - Will follow any developments closelyTransport minister Baroness Sugg said: The current position is more information is needed to warrant any grounding decision.But former pilot and Labour peer Lord Tunniclfe has urged the Government to immediately ground the plane following the crash.He said: In my day we had a rule - If it can go wrong it will go wrong. The industry seems to have lost sight of this rule. I believe everybody involved will be shown to be in dereliction of their duty.Sunday’s tragedy follows the Lion Air flight that went down over the Java Sea in late October, killing all  people on board.Boeing has now revealed it was developing software following the Lion Air disaster that would make an already safe aircraft even safer.If this isnt listed,get in touch with the airline by phone or the internet to ask what plane is used one that route.The airlines website should be able to tell youyou have already booked a trip using your booking reference.You can also check an aviation tracking website or app such as Flightradar and FlightAware.This will require a flight number to find out which plane or planes are typically used on a certain route.Alternatively, use the planes registration number to look up details, including the type of plane and how old it is, on a public database run by a civil aviation body.In the UK, this means checking the Civil Aviation Authoritys website.Following the Indonesia crash, questions were raised over the safety of the planes after investigators said there were problems with its airspeed indicator and angle of attacksensors.This led to fears the jets could have a fault that causes them to nose-e.A warning was sent to operators about the sensor problem after it emerged the Lion air flight suffered issues the day before the crash.But the US Federal Aviation Administration has told airlines it believes Boeings  Max  model to be airworthy.A latest version of the best-selling commercial jet in history, the Boeing  Max  is operated by scores of airlines around the world - including in the UK.There are currently  in service with airlines around the world - but thousands more are on order.The model is one of four ieties of  Max aircraft produced by the US aerospace giant.Boeing says it has taken more than , orders for the single-aisle family of planes which can carry up to  passengers.In Britain, holiday operator Tui Airways has ordered  Max aircraft as part of a major fleet overhaul and took delivery of its first Max  in December.TUIShenzhen AirlinesChina Eastern AirlinesAir ChinaChina SouthernHainan AirlinesShanghai AirlinesXiamen AirlinesShandong AirlinesOkay AirwaysKunming AirlinesEthiopian AirlinesCayman AirwaysGaruda IndonesiaLion AirComairGol AirwaysAeromexicoAerolineas ArgentinasSilkAirTui was the first UK-registered airline to receive one of the new Boeing aircraft and planned to roll out its orders over the next five years.Based at Manchester Airport, the planes are due to ferry passengers to a range of holiday destinations from the north-west.The carriers German parent company is reported to have bought  Max s.Other airlines in Europe to use the Max aircraft include Air Italy, Lot Polish Airlines and Norwegian.The flight came down just after departing Addis Ababa carrying  passengers from  countries and eight crew members.Among those who died were nine British citizens, eight Americans and Italians,  Kenyans, nine Ethiopians, eight Chinese, seven French,  Canadians, one Irish, six Egyptians, five from the Netherlands, and four from India and Slovakia.The pilot, who had an excellent flying record, had reported dficulties and asked to turn back, adding the plane had no known technical problems.Senior captain Yared Getachew had a commendable performance having completed more than , hours in the air, an Ethiopian Airlines spokesman said.The plane had flown from Johannesburg to Addis earlier on Sunday morning, undergoing rigorous testing on February , the airline said.A horried witness said it swerved and dipped and was belching smoke from the rear before it crashed.He also said the Boeing  Max  was making a strange noise before hitting the ground with a large boom and a shower of flaming luggage.Crash investigators yesterday recovered the black box flight recorder from a crater the size of a basketball court.The harrowing final seconds of flight ET were revealed by flight radar data, which showed it repeatedly climbed, fell and climbed again soon after takeoffAviation experts said this unstable vertical speed is extremely unusual and planes usually climb steadily.Crash investigators from the US National Transportation Safety Board will arrive today to help piece together what went wrong, the US ambassador to Ethiopia said.The Ethiopian Airlines plane that crashed today was carrying passengers from more than  countries, the airlines CEO told journalists.He said they included  Kenyans,  Canadians, nine Ethiopians, eight Italians, eight Chinese citizens, eight Americans, nine British citizens, seven French citizens, six Egyptians, five Dutch citizens, four Indians, four people from Slovakia, three Austrians, three Swedes, three Russians, two Moroccans, two Spaniards, two Poles and two Israelis.Belgium, Ireland Indonesia, Somalia, Norway, Serbia, Togo, Mozambique, Rwanda, Sudan, Uganda and Yemen each had one citizen onboard.Four of those onboard were listed as using United Nations passports and their nationalities were not immediately clear.It had been reported seven Brits were among the dead but last night two more were added to the toll.Victims include UN worker Joanna Toole, , from Exmouth, Devon, aid worker Sam Pegram, , from Penwortham, Lancs, Plymouth uni graduate Sarah Auffret, who also had French nationality, probation worker Joseph Waithaka, , of Hull, and Somali-born mum and son Sarah Hassan Said and Nasrudin Abdulkadir. UN engineer Michael Ryan, of Cork, Ireland, was also among the dead.The state-owned Ethiopian Airlines calls itself Africas largest carrier and has ambitions of becoming the gateway to the continent.Its last major crash was in January , when a flight from Beirut went down shortly after take-off.The British death toll was today revised from seven to at least nine.The Foreign Office said: Our staff at the British Embassy in Addis Ababa are continuing to work with the relevant authorities in Ethiopia to obtain further information.Among the British victims are Sam Pegram, , from Penwortham, Lancashire, who worked for the Norwegian Refugee Council and was on his way to Nairobi.Many of the  passengers were heading to a United Nations environment conference in Nairobi, including animal expert Joanna Toole, , from Devon.Polar tourism expert Sarah Auffret, who had dual British and French nationality, and dad Joseph Waithaka, , from Hull, also died.

title: brit mum brazilian bum lift turkey
story: Leah Cambridge, from Leeds, West Yorks, collapsed shortly after the op at the clinic loved by Towie stars, including Lauren Goodger.The -year-old is said to have arranged to have the surgery through a firm named Elite Aftercare, which acts as a go-between linking clients and surgeons.Wakefield Coroners Court had previously been told how she travelled to Izmir in August last year to have the butt lt, but died following complications in the procedure.During a pre-inquest review hearing today, the mum-of-threes partner, Scott Franks, revealed how she had been interested in having the surgery for some time.He said: She spoke with me regarding it on several occasions, and it was obvious that she was quite interested in doing it for some time.Obviously shes booked it and just gone, and thats it, shes gone.Mr Franks also said his girlfriend, who has three boys, was told that she would need to put on just over a stoneprior to having the work done.Speaking about Ms Cambridge, the familys representative Richard Paige told the inquest: This was very much done on her own volition.Mr Paige also quoted a report from the British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeonswhich suggests that the Brazilian buttock lt has the highest death rate, believed to be as high as one in every , operations, of all cosmetic surgery procedures.The report, issued in October last year, suggests that surgeons refrain from performing the treatment until more data can be obtained, due to the risk of injecting fat into large veins that can travel to the heart or brain and cause severe illness and death.The controversial op involves taking fat from other areas of the body and injecting it into the glutes and bum to make them bigger.But,its not done correctly, it can cause serious problems, Professor for aesthetic surgery Jim Frame from Anglia Ruskin University warned.To be successful, a fat graft needs nutrition and so has to be injected into tissue that has a blood supply, Prof Frame said.Fat has more chance of staying in placeit is inserted into muscle – but this is where the risk lies.Injecting fat into the buttocks can easily lead to serious problemsdone incorrectly. These include a fat embolism, when fat enters the bloodstream and blocks a blood vessel.In the lungs, for example, it blocks oxygen from entering the bloodstream, while in the brain it can cause a stroke – both can be fatal.Cheap overseas clinics are contributing to a rise in deaths from having the procedure, Prof Frame, a senior consultant surgeon at Springfield Hospital, Chelmsford, said.Last year a survey of  surgeons from across the world found  patients had died from a condition called a fat embolism - where the injected fat travels to other parts of the body that it shouldnt.Most of these deaths appear to have been caused by inappropriately qualied practitioners working in non-approved facilities, including homes and garages, he added.Other post-surgery problems, such as gangrene and sepsis, can also be fatal.Sarah Hemingway, representing Elite Aftercare at the inquest, told how the firm does not directly employ the surgeons themselves, and has no formal contract with the hospital involved in the surgery.But Mr Paige explained how the companys website claims to employ the best surgeons and nurses for procedures.The inquest also heard how Ms Cambridge had been asked to fill in a patient information anaesthesia form prior to travelling for the surgery, but no direct contact was made between Elite Aftercare and her GP.A provisional post-mortem examination had previously revealed that the mum died from a fat embolism caused by a cosmetic surgical procedure.It had been reported that the beautician had been paranoid about having excess stomach weight from having children, and opted for the butt lt procedure, which involves the reshaping of the buttocks by transferring fat from other areas including the stomach and back.Reports in the aftermath of her death told how Ms Cambridge had three heart attacks during the operation, which took place on August  last year.Patients make appointments at a UK office before travelling to Turkey for the surgery.The clinic’s website claims: “Elite Aftercare aims to provide a UK standard of care.”One reality star who had surgery there said last year: “It’s not a dodgy back street clinic.“I weighed up whether to have my nose job in the UK or over there and chose Turkey.“They’re constantly checking you’re all OK. They’re not going to discharge youthey don’t think you’re fit to leave the hospital. I was fine.”During Tuesdays hearing, the coroner suggested that a three-day inquest into her death would take place in early July, focusing on the contact between Ms Cambridge and Elite Aftercare, any pre-assessments done prior to the treatment, and the procedure itself.The controversial Brazilian butt lt, made famous by US reality TV star Kim Kardashian, involves taking fat from the waist or stomach and inserting it in the buttocks.The operation takes between one and two hours and involves a tiny cannula being inserted into a mm hole to extract fat.The fat is then puried and re-injected into the buttocks.According to Elite Aftercares website, Towie stars Lauren Goodger and Amber Dowding and Geordie Shore’s Chloe Ferry, have had procedures there.Former Spurs footballer Jamie OHara also had liposuction at the same Izmir clinic last year after piling on the pounds by scoffing junk food on Celebrity Big Brother.

title: luckiest woman world buys wins 30 lottery tickets
story: Deborah Brown from Richmond, Virginia, said she first bought  tickets with the combination --- at a petrol station.But she then started seeing the same four digits throughout the day - so tested her luck further by buying another ten tickets at the same location, NBC reports.Virginia’s Pick  game lets players choose a single, four-digit number between  and .A winning number is then picked twice a day, and anyone carrying a ticket bearing that number nets them , .On the night of February , each of Browns  plays won the top prize in the draw, netting her , .I nearly had a heart attack, Brown said, according to a statement from Virginia Lottery.The odds of matching all four numbers in order are  in ,, the agency said.Brown has said she has no immediate plans for her winnings, but may renovate her home.John Hagerty, a spokesman for Virginia Lottery, said buying more than one ticket with the same series of numbers does not improve the chance of winning because only one series can win in each drawing.He added that it was unusual, but not unprecedented, that Ms Brown had picked the same combination for all her tickets.“In general, people who buy multiple tickets will spread the numbers around,” he said.“But we do see people buy multiple tickets with the same numbers in order to increase that prize.“And sometimes it works.

title: bullied pupil cries classmates surprise gift tennessee
story: Azrael Robinson, , from Tennessee, US, was given a new pair of trainers by his friends in recognition of his selfless behaviour towards others.The teenager, who attends LaVergne High School, had previously been bullied at another school.In the viral clip, Azrael starts to sob when he unwraps and opens the box to reveal an expensive pair of Nike shoes.Two of his pals had presented him with the generous gt along with some cash and new clothes to say thank you for his kindness towards his fellow classmates.One of the pupil’s sister posted the video of the moment online.She wrote: “Today, my little sister sent me a video of what they did for one of their classmates, that’s having a hard time.“They all got together and bought him some shoes, and also donated clothes to this kid. ‘This video is so emotional  filled with love.“You just never know what kids go through, but it’s kids like them, that gives us hope.”The boy’s teacher Sonji Newman spoke to TODAY about Azrael’s kindness towards others.She said: “If they don’t understand something, he’s the first one to help.“If anything is dropped in the classroom, he’s the first one to pick it up.“If a student is down, he’s the first one to say everything is going to be okay.“They just wanted to give to him to make him feel better about himself. He was so grateful and so full of love. He just appreciated it so much.”Azrael’s mum Traci also said her son was so overwhelmed by the touching gt that he cried the whole way home.

title: brexit vote live updates latest news theresa may deal
story: The Prime Minister failed to win over enough MPs to push her Brexit agreement through the Commons as they feared it would still keep us tied to the EU for years to come. MPs voted for the deal and  voted against the deal.MPs on all sides of the Tory party came out this afternoon to say they cant back her deal as it would tie us to the EU and not deliver a proper Brexit.  The Labour boss looked pretty pleased as he left Parliament tonight.But Chancellor Philip Hammond looked a bit glum in comparison.Hes due to give his spring statement to MPs tomorrow too, lucky him.Theresa May hasnt discussed resigning with her top team either, her spokesperson has said.Mrs May clings on, for now#mdash Nick GutteridgeMarch , The PM has no plans for more talks with the EU, her spokesperson said tonight. Her political spokesman said May would set out how she intended to vote on Wednesday.Andrea Leadsom says its still the Governments intention to leave on March . Its looking less and less likely#Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: jean claude juncker makes tasteless joke about not getting enough sleep last night because of theresa may
story: The EU Commission boss told MPs he didnt sleep much last night because of Mrs May after the pair were locked in late night talks in Strasbourg yesterday.Ill let you in on a secret, he told MEPs earlier.But he did say his sleep was long enough to be able to dream of Slovakia.Talks finally broke up just before midnight in France yesterday. The pair then went on to go and do a press conference to waiting reporters over what theyd signed up to.Mrs May managed to get the bloc to sign up to legally binding tweaks to the deal, and put out a statement saying the UK could try and pull out of the hated backstopwe got trapped.Mr Juncker warned MPs the concessions were MPs last chance to pass a deal and said there would be no further changes at all.I would therefore like British MPs to support the measures, which are both British and European and which have taken form in agreed texts, an agreement at EU level.Mr Junckers comments came as the PM is fighting desperately to save her fledging deal.She turned up this afternoon with a croaky voice after the late night talks.You should hear Jean Claude Juncker! she joked.The clearly tired PM begged MPs to get behind the deal and said it was the choice between this and perhaps no Brexit at all.But her Tories arent convinced that this will be enough to stop them get onside, and make sure we can get out of the backstopthe EU tried to keep us in.Now it looks likely that MPs could vote against a No Deal Brexit tomorrow - and vote to extend Article  to buy more time to figure out what to do.

title: britain could face election no deal or second referendum after crunch brexit vote tonight
story: What happens next could throw Brexit off completely now, and the future is far from certain.The PM stood up after she lost the vote and confirmed that two more votes will come in the following days.ALL OUT FOR NO DEALMPs will tomorrow vote on whether or not to leave the EU with No Deal in  days time, the PM confirmed tonight.Brexiteers want Mrs May to urge all Tories to back that option rather than risk a delay.But at least a dozen ministers would probably resign rather than vote for No Deal, meaning the option may have trouble getting through the Commons.DITHER AND DELAYIf the Commons votes against No Deal on Wednesday, there will be a further vote on Thursday allowing MPs to delay Brexit.A delay would require the permission of all EU member states and could probably be no longer than two months.It would raise the prospect of a much softer Brexit as Tory Remainers team up with Labour to keep Britain in the EU customs union.POLL DANCECharles Walker, vice-chair of the Tories powerful  Committee, warned that a defeat on the deal would end up leading to a snap election.He said today: If it doesnt go through tonight, as sure as night follows day, there will be a general election within a matter of days or weeks. It is not sustainable, the current situation in Parliament.I dont think people have grasped thatyou cant govern a country, you cant go on for weeks, months, years. You have to go and get a new mandate.The Tories have taken a large lead over Labour in recent opinion polls - possibly putting them on track for a hefty majority.CONFIDENCE TRICKJeremy Corbyn could trigger a second vote of no confidence in the Government later this week.Mrs May would probably survive - with even Tory rebels falling in line to stop Labour securing a General Election.NOT ANOTHER ONEToday one of Mrs Mays allies publicly floated the prospect of a snap General Electionthe PMs Brexit strategy is killed off.Andshe doesnt trigger an election herself, Labour could launch a no-confidence vote to force her out.EXIT FROM BREXITSecond referendum campaigners are still adamant that Brexit may not end up happening at all.The Lib Dems, Independent Group and SNP are all united behind a so-called Peoples Vote - and Jeremy Corbyn could join them.

title: eu chiefs says nothing more that we can do after brexit vote is crushed again
story: Brussels bosses said they had done all they could to try and push the deal through, but now it was up to the UK to find a way forward.Donald Tusk, President of the European Commission, said that tonights vote hugely increases the chances the UK will leave without a deal and they will continue their emergency plans.He said in a statement just minutes after Theresa Mays agreement was slapped down for the second time: We regret the outcome of tonights vote and are disappointed that the UK government has been unable to ensure a majority for the Withdrawal Agreement agreed by both parties in November.Mr Tusk said on the EU side we have done all that is possible to reach an agreement... it is dficult to see what more we can do.A solution can only be found in London, he claimed.And he hinted the EU will be on hand to extend Article Mrs May asks for it in the coming days.He said the bloc would consider it and decide by unanimity.But they will expect a clear plan for the extension too, he warned.And Mr Barnier, who was last night in last minute talks with the PM, added: The EU has done everything it can to help get the Withdrawal Agreement over the line. The impasse can only be solved in the #UK. Our “no-deal” preparations are now more important than ever before.However, a commission spokesperson said tonight that it had also increased the risk that Brexit might not happen at all - hinting that Britain could hold a second referendum or stop Brexit.The comments come despite the fact that MPs only rejected the deal because they thought the EU were being too harsh and there was a chance wed stay trapped in the bloc forever.The House of Commons tonight voted against the PMs Brexit deal for the second time - by a margin of  votes to .Now  days after the referendum, and with just  days before Brexit, Brits are still in the dark about when orwe will ever leave the EU.Furious MPs blasted the uncertainty - saying the wretched soap opera of Brexit continues as the country heads back to square one.

title: no deal brexit explained brussels eu theresa may corbyn
story: But what does it meanBritain leaves the European Union without a deal  Heres what we know about this fast-changing situation.A No Deal departure from the European Union means leaving without formal arrangements for the future relationship or any transition period.Currently Britains trade, customs and immigration rules are tied up with the single market and a host of EU regulatory bodies.Ministers are seeking a legal deal to replace these with looser arrangements so we are outside the single market and customs union but keeping close ties so cross-border trade is easy.Negotiations under Article  of the Lisbon Treaty led to the withdrawal agreement in November - but MPs rejected it in January.Theresa May headed to Brussels on February  with fresh plans to fix the hated Irish border backstop.And the PM also jetted to Strasbourg on the eve of the March  meaningful vote, apparently in a bid to get further assurances from the EU.If Parliament cannot support a deal - and there is no extension - the UK will leave the EU without a deal on March .That would mean the UK being treated as a third country by the EU with commerce governed by World Trade Organisation rules, experts say.Some Brexiteers say that could be positive - opening up trade with the rest of the world - but many people fear chaos.On January , Boris Johnson said that a No Deal Brexit is the closest to what people voted for in the referendum.He also urged Cabinet Ministers to mirror the British publics optimism and self-confidence for the possible exit scenario.A poll by YouGov on January  revealed that  per cent of the British public think a No Deal Brexit is likely,  per cent think a failed deal will result in a second referendum,  per cent said the deal will pass and  per cent said a better deal could be negotiated.Eleventh hour talks for a new Brexit deal were on the verge of collapse this week as EU chiefs clashed bitterly with Cabinet ministers in Brussels.British and EU negotiators hit deadlock over a compromise on the Irish backstop.Parliament tonightdealt a major blow to Theresa May, resoundingly rejecting her Brexit deal just  days before the UK is due to leave the bloc.MPS rejected the PMs Brexit deal despite her assurance that new agreements reached with Jean-Claude Juncker in Strasbourg would ensure the UK cannot be trapped in the controversial backstop arrangement indefinitely.It means that Britain has been plunged into chaos -  days after the referendum, and with just  days before Brexit - as Brits are still in the dark about when, orwe will ever leave the EU.Following the vote, a spokesman for European Council president Donald Tusk said: On the EU side we have done all that is possible to reach an agreement.Given the additional assurances provided by the EU in December, January and yesterday, it is dficult to see what more we can do.If there is a solution to the current impasse it can only be found in London.Brexiteers say it would be a boost for the UK to be free from Brussels rules and we will be able to strike deals with other upcoming nations around the globe.We would also not be obliged to pay the £billion orce bill, according to a House of Commons report — but Chancellor Philip Hammond sparked fury by saying we would pay up even without a deal.Many people fear the UK economy would be hurt by a clf edge Brexit as trade is held up by new border checks and tarfs and more red tape for businesses.Doom-monger Bank of England governor Mark Carney has warned house prices could crash by a third in a worst-case scenario.Customs checks on cross-Channel freight could cause havoc at ports, hitting food supplies and other goods such a motor parts.The Border Force is also planning for a possible No Deal Brexit as they fear there will be signicant outbound queues at the Eurostar and a degradation of border security, Sky News reported.In a pure No Deal Brexit scenario, businesses would lose their passporting rights, which allow them to sell their services across the EU without having to obtain licences in each inidual country.The  mile frontier between Northern Ireland and the Republic could become a hard border, according to Eurocrats in Brussels.The EUs rules may require Ireland to impose customs and other checks to protect the bloc’s border – which some say would mark ato the dark days of the Troubles.It could blow a hole in the Good Friday Agreement, with pressure on all sides to find a compromise.The Confederation of British Industry also said a No Deal Brexit would wipe £billion off the UK economy, making every region poorer, the Daily Mail reported.Theresa Mays Withdrawal agreement has been negotiated with Brussels.But MPs rejected it when it was voted on in parliament in January.Mrs May suffered the biggest parliamentary defeat of any British Prime Minister when the Withdrawal agreement was rejected by a majority of .Another todays meaningful vote also crashed, there are just over two weeks before Britain is due to leave the European Union.With Parliament rejecting the PMs deal tonight, politicians will now vote on whether to crash out of the EU with or without a deal tomorrow, on March .This is in line with a promise set out by Mrs May last month.Mrs May announced that she will grant Conservative MPs a free vote on a motion stating that this House declines to approve leaving the European Union without a Withdrawal Agreement and a framework on the future relationship on March   and notes that leaving without a deal remains the default in UK and EU law unless this House and the EU raty an agreement.If MPs reject no-deal as most Westminster observers expect, a THIRD vote will follow on Thursday on whether to authorise Mrs May to ask for an extension of the two-year Article  negotiation process.A Labour Party spokesman said: Allowing a free vote on no deal shows Theresa May has given up any pretence of leading the country.Once again, shes putting her partys interests ahead of the public interest.Parliament previously voted that May must seek alternative arrangements to prevent a hard border in Northern Ireland.Eurocrat Michel Barnier has tabled an offer that would allow Britain to quit the customs union rather than being trapped in the backstop.But the plan would see Northern Ireland staying tied to the EU - effectively creating a border inside the United Kingdom.Ministers have previously announced plans for troops on the street and emergency ferries to cope with a No Deal Brexit.They will order businesses and families to start preparing for Britain to leave the EU without a deal and release £billion of extra spending.Ministers also unveiled the post-Brexit immigration system, which will end preferential treatment for EU migrants.Theresa May’s Government was plunged into utter disarray over Brexit just  hours before a crunch Cabinet meeting over Britain’s future.In December , Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt insisted Britain could “flourish and prosper”it walks away from the EU with No Deal.As bitter Brexit battles raged on:Businesses received a -page document about Brexit, with a total of , firms likely to hear from the Government.The papers showed:

title: brexit how 24 hours before
story: NewsBrexit: How the  hours before Theresa Mays disastrous deal defeat unfoldedA last-ditch dash to France for late night talks came to nothing - all because of a member of her own CabinetShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe seeds of her defeat were sown in the last few months - but she couldnt reverse them in time "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email When MPs filed through the ision lobbies to deliver their verdict on Theresa May s latest Brexit plan it was the climax of the most dramatic  hours yet for Brexit.A last-ditch, cross-Channel dash to France for crisis talks, a late-night press conference, a tense showdown with Tory MPs, and a devastating legal opinion from the Government’s top law officer fuelled the turmoil gripping British politics. The Prime Minister spent part of Monday afternoon in the sanctuary of Westminster Abbey attending a service to mark Commonwealth Day. Back in No, officials were hastily drawing-up plans to fly her to Strasbourg for emergency negotiations with EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker.   At RAF Northolt in north-west London, troops were preparing a BAe plane from NoSquadron, The Queen’s Flight, for imminent departure. Swept from the Abbey in her armoured Jaguar XJL and escorted by four motorcycle outriders, diabetic Mrs May could have been forgiven for reaching for the stash of Jelly Babies and other sweets stuffed into the back pocket of a front seat of the bomb-proof limousine, stored there to boost her blood sugar levels. After a quick change of clothes in No, the PM’s blue-light convoy raced through the capital’s windy streets on its -mile journey along the A to Northolt where, on the runway, her jet was ready for the -mile sortie to the French border city. Less than an hour later, the Tory chief was meeting Mr Juncker to sign off what Mrs May hoped would be the clinching revision to get her deal through Parliament. At pm, her de facto deputy David Lidington stood at the Commons Despatch Box to tell MPs legally binding changes to the Withdrawal Agreement had been won. Back in Strasbourg, weary Mrs May - her voice struggling as it did during the run-up to her disastrous  party conference speech - and Mr Juncker sat behind a desk to face the Press and deliver the fruits of their negotiating teams’ labours.   “Today we have secured legal changes,” claimed the PM, whose original pact suffered a crushing -vote defeat in January. “Now is the time to come together, to back this improved Brexit deal, and to deliver on the instruction of the British people.” Insisting the revision was final, exasperated Mr Juncker added: “There will be no new negotiations. It is this.” Mrs May was whisked back to the airport and ed to London, steeling herself for the dficult day ahead. At .am she held her daily meeting with her closest advisers. Thirty minutes later, the European Research Group’s eight lawyers began poring over the new deal to decidethey could back it. Meanwhile, Mrs May hosted the weekly meeting of her top ministers in Downing Street from .am. “Cabinet gave its backing to the agreement and stressed the huge importance of the meaningful vote passing this evening,” the PM’s spokesman said later.   Mrs May thanked Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay and Attorney General Geoffrey Cox for their hard work, closing the meeting of senior ministers by saying, ominously: “Today is the day.” But any hope she may have had of unlikely victory was extinguished at am when Mr Cox dropped a bombshell on the PM’s chances of success. The celebrated QC’s three-page legal advice to Mrs May contained  paragraphs. The final one drove a stake into the heart of her revamped pact. According to the Attorney’s letter, the “legal risk” of the UK being unable to leave the Irish Backstop - designed to prevent a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republicthe UK and EU cannot agree terms of a future trade deal - “remains unchanged”. Half an hour later, Mrs May appeared before her harshest Brexit critics - the Conservatives’  Backbench Committee. Flanked by her bodyguards, the PM walked a gauntlet of journalists before entering the Attlee Room at Portcullis House.   Inside the secret meeting, she pleaded with Tory MPs not to torpedo her deal. One backbencher cheered Mrs May, telling her: “You haven’t quite pulled a rabbit out of the hat, but you’ve pulled out a hamster and that’s good enough for me.” Building up the sense of theatre, MP George Freeman said later: “You can hear the collective sound of collective pennies dropping as to just how serious this is.” Ministers also attempted to put a positive spin on the PM’s chances. Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd said: “I think she’ll win tonight. I think we’ll all win tonight.” Askedhe thought the deal would get through, Environment Secretary Michael Gove said simply: “Yes.” At the same time, Brexit Secretary Mr Barclay was being grilled by the Commons Brexit Committee, admitting the UK’s departure could be delayed beyond March . “There may be the need for a technical extension,” he confessed.

story: NewsBrexit: Theresa May confirms Tories will get a free vote on no-deal exit from EUThe Prime Minister confirmed the vote on whether to approve crashing out without a deal will take place tomorrowShareByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video theresa-responds-wake-parliament-rejecting-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa May has confirmed Tory MPs will get a free vote on no-deal Brexit tomorrow.The Prime Minister made the concession after suffering another embarrassing drubbing from MPs on her Brexit deal. Speaking after losing the vote by  to , she said: I profoundly regret the decision that this House has taken tonight. Mrs May confirmed the promised vote on no-deal would go ahead tomorrow. And she said: This is an issue of grave importance for the future of our country. Just like the referendum, there are strongly held and equally legitimate views on both sides. For that reason, I can confirm that this will be a free vote on this side of the House.   She confirmed the wording of the motion will be: That this House declines to approve leaving the European Union without a Withdrawal Agreement and a Framework on the Future Relationship on  March  and notes that leaving without a deal remains the default in UK and EU law unless this House and the EU raty an agreement.” If MPs decline to leave without a deal, a further vote will take place on Thursday on extending Article . Mrs May said: If the House votes for an extension, the Government will seek to agree that extension with the EU and bring forward the necessary legislation to change the exit date commensurate with that extension. But let me be clear. Voting against leaving without a deal and for an extension does not solve the problems we face.   She added: The EU will want to know what use we mean to make of such an extension.This House will have to answer that question. Does it wish to revoke Article   Does it want to hold a second referendum  Or does it want to leave with a deal but not this deal  These are unenviable choices, but thanks to the decision the House has made this evening they must now be faced.

title: brexit theresa mays croaky voice
story: NewsopinionBrexit: How Theresa Mays croaky voice meant her plan went out with a whisperSKETCH: Theresa May has battled with a cold before - but this time the cold was on the winning sideShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsopinionthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video theresa-lose-voices-commons-during-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLast time Theresa May lost her voice this badly was during her speech to Tory conference - and her biggest problem was a backdrop that fell apart. Today, her voice crumbled again - but this time her problem was a backstop that was far too sturdy. The PMs most loyal supporter, her husband, watched every croaking, gasping minute of the Prime Minister’s speech as she tried to defend the meagre concessions she had dragged home from Strasbourg. Sitting in the public gallery, Philip May winced with every cracked word and grinned when she managed enough breath to heave an attack at an opposition MP.   Tory MP Charlie Elphicke told Mrs May earlier in the day that her new deal wasn’t so much a “rabbit out of the hat” as it was a hamster. As she stood rasping at the despatch box, she sounded rather like she had swallowed that hamster and it was trying to claw its way out again. It came to ‘Quiet Man’ Iain Duncan Smith to mount a rescue attempt for the Prime Minister’s vocal chords. The Brexiteer leaned over from his back-bench seat on a mission of mercy, delivering a much needed Strepsil. But it didn’t much matter by that point. A much louder man had already sealed her fate.   Earlier Geoffrey Cox, the government’s booming-voiced lawyer, did his usual Gandalf impression as he outlined his legal opinion of the new concessions. But he couldn’t bring himself to say the risk of the Northern Ireland backstop becoming permanent had gone - only that it had been “reduced.” Nothing had changed. And one by one, MPs told Tory Gandalf: “This shall not pass!” One Number  aide was overheard complaining that the Prime Minister had been “Cox-blocked”. And as Theresa May drove back to Downing Street in the dramatically pouring rain, she couldn’t escape the sense that her Brexit plan had ended not with a bang, but with a whisper.

title: brexit what happens next after
story: NewsBrexit: What happens next after Theresa Mays deal suffers crushing defeatThere are now just days for Mrs May or Parliament to take control of the Brexit negotiationsShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsTheresa May has a major battle ahead "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMPs have delivered a brutal verdict on Theresa Mays deal - heaping yet another defeat on the Prime Ministers plan.There are now just days for Mrs May or Parliament to take control of the Brexit negotiation.In the coming days MPs will face a number of crunch votes. They will debate delaying Brexit andwe should rule out leaving with No Deal. The now very fluid situation could also see MPs rule out leaving the EU at all or agree to hold a second referendum. This is the guide for what could happen in the next few days as British politics enters its most unpredictable period in living memory.  MPs tomorrow will debate scrapping the chance of a no-deal Brexit. Under plans outlined by the Prime Minister on February , the Commons will have the option to vote on removing the possibility of the UK quitting the EU without an agreement. Theresa May controversially confirmed it will be a free vote to avoid a slew of Tory resignations. Businesses, experts and campaigners have repeatedly warned of a chaotic, economic doomsdayBritain was to plunge from the bloc minus a orce deal and transition period.Lorries could be stacked on roads leading to Channel ports, supermarket shelves may be emptied and vital medicine supplies might be disrupted, according to worst-case scenarios.But Theresa May has so far kept the option on the table, believing it is a key negotiating tactic.However, despite her desperation to preserve the possibility, there is no majority in Parliament for a no-deal departure.   If it comes to a vote tomorrow night MPs are likely to deliver a resounding “No” to no-deal. Only a hardcore rump of Tories and some DUP MPs believe a no-deal - where the UK reverts to World Trade Organisation rules, raising the prospect of tarfs on a host of products - could be good for the country. Will Brexit be delayed  A vote on delaying Brexit is due to take place Thursday - and could finally dash the hopes of Leave supporters who were promised the UK would cease to be a member of the EU at pm on March . MPs are set to be given the chance to delay Article  - the formal mechanism for leaving the bloc - under plans unveiled in the Commons. The PM has always been adamant the UK will leave on March  - two years after formally triggering Article  - so any delay would be a severe humiliation. It would also fuel suspicions the UK will never leave - overturning the “will of the people”.   A short delay could happen regardless because evenMrs May manages to force through a deal at a third attempt, there maybe too little time left to pass the Withdrawal Agreement Bill through the Commons and Lords before scheduled departure day. The Government must table an amendable motion within seven sitting days of last night’s defeat - so by next Thursday. Experts say this means the PM will have lost control of the process, with Parliament in pole position to decide what happens next. However, the law of the land states the UK leaves the EU on March . That can only be stopped by changing the law - and time is running out. If the UK wants a delay, it has to ask for one from Brussels. The PM is due at a crunch summit in the city next Thursday where leaders could thrash out plans for a delay - or offer her another revision. The EU is likely to grant an extension of no more than two months - any longer, and the UK would be required to take part in EU Parliament elections. Will there be a general election  Mrs May is said to favour a general election over a second referendum, but neither option appeals to the premier.She is scarred by her disastrous  campaign where she was unable to resist a -point poll lead over Labour and triggered an unnecessary snap election, surrendering the Conservatives’ majority just two years after it was won by David Cameron. The PM’s “strong and stable” slogan backfired as Labour surged in the election day run-in, with Jeremy Corbyn resurrecting his leadership and performing much better than expected.  However, some polls in recent weeks have given the Tories a -point lead and Mrs May might fancy her chances of ballot box redemption. But the uncomfortable truth for the PM - and all MPs - is a new election could leave the parliamentary arithmetic largely unchanged: the Tories could still be the biggest party but wield no overall majority, and many Conservative MPs could still oppose Mrs May’s Withdrawal Agreement, The PM could find herself back at square one. Will there be a second referendum  Campaigners for another EU vote are biding their time before tabling an amendment demanding a re-run of the hugely isive  referendum. They want to exploit their “moment of maximum opportunity”, which may now be very near. Supporters of another vote claim voters should have the chance to back the PM’s deal or opt to Remain after all. But critics say the public has already decided to Leave, with ,, people backing Brexit and ,, wanting to stay in the EU - a majority of ,, to quit. Mrs May is dead against another EU referendum - and being forced to accept one may prove fatal to her premiership. Mr Corbyn has pledged to throw Labour’s weight behind a “People’s Vote”. But suspicions linger that he favours withdrawal - and the party leader continues to face anger over his apparent lack of enthusiasm for the EU during the  referendum campaign. Can May survive  Under normal circumstances, a PM who suffered a -vote defeat - the biggest ever in parliamentary history - on such an important motion as January’s meaningful vote would be expected to resign. But these are very far from normal times and Mrs May shrugged off the reverse and vowed to try again. Members of her own party tried and failed to oust her in December by tabling a vote of no confidence. She survived the vote by  votes to  - meaning more than third of her MPs wanted to topple her.   The victory - however hollow - meant Mrs May cannot face a fresh attempt to remove her as leader for another  months. In January, her Government survived a no-confidence vote by  votes to  after rebel Tory MPs and the DUP backed the Government just  hours after they combined to crush her original Brexit plan.Labour can table as many no-confidence votes as it likes, but Tories and the DUP are likely to continue to support Mrs Mays administration because they fear handing power to Mr Corbyn - and losing a confidence to vote would trigger a general election.

title: how legal advice undid prime
story: NewsHow the legal advice from Geoffrey Cox undid the Prime Ministers Brexit dealAttorney General Geoffrey Coxs legal advice dealt Theresa May a devastating blowShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsGeoffrey Cox may not be Theresa Mays favourite person right now "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May had hoped that the legal advice doled out by her Attorney General would persuade wavering MPs to back her deal. But the Government’s top legal advisor dealt a fatal blow to the Prime Minister’s hopes ofgetting her deal through when he said that the latest version would not allow the UK to leave the backstop unilaterally. On Tuesday night she was defeated by  votes - almost  votes less than in January suggesting some MPs were won over. But it just wasnt enough.In January Theresa May vowed to win “not a further exchange of letters, but a signicant and legally binding change to the withdrawal agreement.”Mrs May dashed to Strasbourg on Monday to finalise a deal with European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker which she said would deliver legally-binding reassurances for MPs to ensure the Irish backstop cannot be permanent. Eurosceptics fear that the Irish backstop, as written, could keep the UK trapped in a partial union with Europe permanently.  And Mr Cox was not able to categorically allay those fears. What was agreed in Strasbourg   On Monday Theresa May dashed to Strasbourg to finalise a deal with European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker which she said would deliver “legally-binding” reassurances for MPs to ensure the Irish backstop cannot be permanent. Jean-Claude Junker and Theresa May agreed a “joint instrument” setting out the legally-binding nature of their promises to seek alternative arrangements to avoid the need for a backstop. The pair also signed up to a “supplement” to November’s Political Declaration making clear that they will seek swtly to seal a deal on their new trade and security relationship. Alongside these documents was a “unilateral declaration by the UK”on the temporary nature of the backstop, which will sit alongside the Withdrawal Agreement. This says that it isthe UK’s understandingthatthe EU doesn’t keep up its end of the bargain in the future relationship negotiations, Britain can pull out of the backstop on its own. It’s unclearthis will be enough to satisfy Geoffrey Cox that the UK can leave unilaterally.What does the Attorney General advise   The Attorney said that the documents agreed in Strasbourg “reduce the risk that the United Kingdom could be indefinitely and involuntarily detained” in the backstopthe EU fails to show good faith in negotiating a trade deal to replace it. But he warned that the question of whether a satisfactory agreement on a future UK EU relationship can be reached remains “a political judgment”. And he said “the legal risk remains unchanged” thatno such agreement can be reached due to “intractable dferences”, the UK would have “no internationally lawful means” of leaving the backstop without EU agreement. In a statement to the Commons, Mr Cox told MPs: “There is no ultimate unilateral right out of this arrangement. The risk of that continues. “But the question is whether it is a likelihood, politically.” Can the UK pull out of the backstop unilaterally   This has been the biggest sticking point for Brexiteers who demanded a way for the UK to leave the backstop without permission from the EU. Or they demanded a time limit. But both of these ideas were rejected by the EU who said that the backstop, which is a form of insurance policy, could not have a time limit - nor could one side  Today the Attorney General said he had never claimed there was an ultimate unilateral right out of this arrangement. He said: The question is whether there is a likelihood, politically... What this document does is address the risk that we could be kept in the backstop by the bad faith and deliberate manipulation of the EU.He continued: It would be a good thingwe could hear from the Labour Party occasionally more than just political shenanigans but some sincere engagement with the real issues this Withdrawal Agreement now raises.What do others say    European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said this is it. No more negotiating. He tweeted after meeting Theresa May: Our agreement provides meaningful clarications and legal guarantees to the Withdrawal Agreement and backstop.The choice is clear, he wrote. It is this deal, or Brexit may not happen at all. Lets bring the UKs withdrawal to an orderly end. We owe it to history.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said Mr Cox had confirmed that no signicant changes had been secured in two months of negotiations and the Governments strategy was in tatters. The Eurosceptic European Research Groups Star Chamber set up to analyse the changes issued its opinion. It said: Yesterdays documents considered inidually and collectively do not deliver legally binding changes to the WA or to theProtocol. They fail to fulfil the commitment made by Government to the House in response to the Brady amendment to obtain legally binding changes to the withdrawal agreement. Crucially, sitting on the  alongside six Tory MPs and an independent QC was Nigel Dodds, Westminster leader of the Democratic Unionist Party. In a statement the DUP indicated it would not support the deal, saying: We recognise that the Prime Minister has made limited progress in her discussions with the European Union. However in our view sufficient progress has not been achieved at this time. In a statement the DUP indicated it would not support the deal, saying: We recognise that the Prime Minister has made limited progress in her discussions with the European Union. However in our view sufficient progress has not been achieved at this time.
